name: 4-20 mA module
info:
The 4-20 mA module has 10 input channels and returns a status of the sensor supplies.

This module requires almost no configuration so it is very easy to use.

The only thing that is really configurable is whether a sensor supply is enabled.

There are 5 sensor supplies available for the 10 channels. So each supply provides for 2 channels. To see the pinout of the module check [the hardware manual](https://gocontroll.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/GOcontroll_Hardware_Manual.pdf).

name: 10 channel input module
info:
The 10 channel input modules are used to read digital or analog (voltage) signals. These are limited by that specific modules capabilities. A 10 channel module is a bit more limitted in what it can do compared to a 6 channel module.

To see the pinout of the module on your specific controller, see [the hardware manual](https://gocontroll.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/GOcontroll_Hardware_Manual.pdf).

name: GOcontroll Modules
info:
Usage of the modules requires a bit of attention from the user, first of all it is ill advised to have any active module nodes when there is a simulink model running on the controller. This will cause bus contention and undefined behaviour, if there is a simulink model running, control the modules from there.

A configured module node will look at /usr/module-firmware/modules.txt to see the current module layout and if it matches what is configured. If modules are switched to a different position you should run the 'go-scan-modules' command in the systems terminal, this will temporarily stop the running simulink model and node-red flow so it has absolute ownership of the module busses and then update the aforementioned modules.txt.

name: 6 channel output module
info:
The 6 channel output is generally the best output module functionality wise, most number of functions and pretty high output current available.
As a safety feature, output modules need to be continuously sent up to date info, because this doesn't really line up with how NodeRED works, the input is buffered and then repeatedly sent in the background untill you update the buffer by giving the node new setpoints.

To see the pinout of the module on your specific controller, see [the hardware manual](https://gocontroll.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/GOcontroll_Hardware_Manual.pdf).

name: 6 channel input module
info:
The 6 channel input modules are used to read digital or analog (voltage) signals. These are limited by that specific modules capabilities. A 10 channel module is a bit more limitted in what it can do compared to a 6 channel module.

To see the pinout of the module on your specific controller, see [the hardware manual](https://gocontroll.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/GOcontroll_Hardware_Manual.pdf).

name: 10 channel output module
info:
The 10 channel output module provides a larger number of less powerfull outputs, they are only rated for a nominal voltage of 1A.

As a safety feature, output modules need to be continuously sent up to date info, because this doesn't really line up with how NodeRED works, the input is buffered and then repeatedly sent in the background untill you update the buffer by giving the node new setpoints.

To see the pinout of the module on your specific controller, see [the hardware manual](https://gocontroll.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/GOcontroll_Hardware_Manual.pdf).

name: Bridge module
info:
The bridge module is the most powerfull output module, but only has 2 channels to control.

To see the pinout of the module on your specific controller, see [the hardware manual](https://gocontroll.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/GOcontroll_Hardware_Manual.pdf).

name: Settings node
info: Its name is a bit deprecated, it will display the GOcontroll software version present on the controller and provides interfaces for uploading your Matlab/Simulink generated binaries and a2ls.

name: Supply and Active
info:
The Controller supply node provides the values from the 4 channel ADC present in the controller.
This can be used to make the controller turn off if all the K15s are low for example.
To turn off the controller the Controller active node can be used.
It can turn off a GPIO pin that keeps the controller alive when all K15s are gone, therefore taking down the controller with it.

This is a very hard reset and can cause data corruption in the ext4 file system so use with care.

name: Auto shutdown
Temperature and leds
info:
The CPU Temperature will send out the CPU temperature every 5 seconds with the key "temperature".
The LED node allows you to control one of the enclosure leds, this can lead to conflicting behaviour when multiple pieces of software try to address the LEDs.

name: GPS
info: The GPS node can be used to read location, altitude and velocity data from the 4G/GPS modem that is optionally available in the Moduline IV and Mini.

name: CAN
info: These two nodes allow you to use the CAN busses present on your controller. Connect can 1 to can 2 and this demo will work.

name: Memory
info: These two blocks allow you to use the file system as a key value store. You can use this as configuration blocks or IPC.

name: Simulink
info:
These two nodes allow for direct IPC to a running simulink model.
This is not thread safe! Especially reading an array from virtual memory can cause corruption, use with care.
